snippet: Other Americans may wonder why Californians, facing The Big One, don't think hard about moving on. Some do, particularly after the endless shocks and aftershocks of the last week. But people in Los Angeles say they are more likely to dwell on more...
lead_paragraph: Other Americans may wonder why Californians, facing The Big One, don't think hard about moving on. Some do, particularly after the endless shocks and aftershocks of the last week. But people in Los Angeles say they are more likely to dwell on more immediate, practical questions. They do not, mostly, ask themselves, When do we leave, but How close is this newest movement of the earth? Is it growing in force? How much more can the chimney take? And why does the dog think I can make it stop? The rumble of a truck laboring up a nearby hill or even a car door slamming can sound like the beginning of something big. But the reaction is hardly ever Whose idea was it to move here in the first place?
